page.title: 03BENENDEN WEALD, LANDSCAPE.
page.content: This small portion of the High Weald of Kent is a hilly one lying along the watershed of the Medway and the Rother. It rises to over 300feet (120 metres) along this line which is followed by the Swattenden Road, (B 2086). This higher area is better drained and mainly cultivated. Even so deciduous woodland with the various varieties of oak predominating is a marked feature of the landscape, with trees and small shaws forming wide green hedges between the fields, so that even farmed land takes on the guise of woodland. We had great difficulty in finding wide views to assess the land-cover of our grid squares. Here the idea of dens as clearings in the forest is well seen on a map or from the air, and the landscape of Adreasweald or Domesday Book is still a reality.
